definition:
All structures share a common signature; the first-order language
$\mathcal{L}$ is the language determined by that signature.

The *theory* of a structure
$\mathcal{M}\text{, }{\operatorname{Th}}(\mathcal{M})\text{,}$ is the
set of all sentences of $\mathcal{L}$ that are true in $\mathcal{M}.$

Structures $\mathcal{M}$ and $\mathcal{N}$ are *elementarily
equivalent*, (in symbols: $\mathcal{M} \equiv \mathcal{N})$ if and only
if
${\operatorname{Th}}(\mathcal{M}) = {\operatorname{Th}}(\mathcal{N})$.
